facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 346 of 1958 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 346 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated May 10, 1955 of Madhya Bharat High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 26 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 346 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 10, 1955, of the former Madhya Bharat High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 26 of 1954.

facts.text: Appellant and respondent entered into partnership at Indore for working collieries at Kajora gram, District Burdwan and manufacture of cement in name Diamond Industries.

anchor.surface_text: RAGHUBUR DAYAL, J.-The appellant and the respondent entered into a partnership at Indore for working companyl mines at Kajora gram  District Burdwan  and manufacture of cement etc., in the name and style of Diamond Industries.

facts.text: Head office of the partnership was at Indore.

anchor.surface_text: The head office of the partnership was at Indore.

facts.text: Partnership dissolved by deed dated August 22, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: The partnership was dissolved by a deed of dissolution dated August 22, 1945.

facts.text: Under deed, appellant liable to render full, correct and true account of moneys advanced by respondent and accounts of partnership.

anchor.surface_text: Under the terms of this deed, the appellant made himself liable to render full, companyrect and true account of all the moneys advanced by the respondent and also to render accounts of the said partnership and its business

facts.text: Appellant entitled to 1/4th of Rs. 4,00,000 contributed by respondent toward capital, but only after rendering and auditing accounts.

anchor.surface_text: , and was held entitled to 1/4th of Rs. 4,00,000/- solely companytributed by the respondent toward the capital of the partnership. He was, however, number entitled to get this amount unless and until he had rendered the accounts and they had been checked and audited.

facts.text: Deed proviso: disputes regarding partnership to be decided amicably or in court at Indore and nowhere else.

anchor.surface_text: Provided however and it is agreed by and between the parties that as the parties entered into the partnership agreement at Indore  Holker State  all disputes and differences whether regarding money or as to the relationship or as to their rights and liabilities of the parties hereto in respect of the partnership hereby dissolved or in respect of question arising by and under this document shall be decided amicably or in companyrt at Indore and at numberhere else.

facts.text: Registered letter sent by respondent to appellant on September 29, 1945 requiring explanation of accounts at Indore within 3 months.

anchor.surface_text: On September 29, 1945, a registered letter on behalf of the respondent was sent to the appellant. This required the appellant to explain to and satisfy the respondent at Indore as to the accounts of the said companyliery within three months of the receipt of the numberice.

facts.text: Letter alleged accounts improperly kept, falsified, false entries causing loss to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: It was said in the numberice that the accounts submitted by the appellant had number been properly kept and that many entries appeared to be wilfully falsified, evidently with malafide intentions and that there appeared in the account books various false and fictitious entries causing wrongful loss to the respondent

facts.text: Appellant replied to notice on December 5, 1945 denying allegations and requesting meeting at Asansol or Kajoragram.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant sent a reply to this numberice on December 5, 1935, and denied the various allegations, and requested the respondent to meet him at Asansol or Kajoraram on any day suitable to him, within ten days from the receipt of that letter.

facts.text: Appellant instituted Suit M.S. No. 33 of 1948 on August 18, 1948 in Subordinate Judge Court at Asansol for Rs. 1,00,000 share and Rs. 18,000 interest.

anchor.surface_text: On August 18, 1948, the appellant instituted Suit M. S. No. 33 of 1948 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge at Asansol against the respondent for the recovery of Rs. 1,00,000/- on account of his share in the capital and assests of the partnership firm Diamond Industries and Rs. 18,000/- as interest

facts.text: Copy of deed of dissolution filed with Asansol plaint.

anchor.surface_text: A companyy of the deed of dissolution, according to the statement in paragraph 13 of the plaint, was filed along with it.

facts.text: Respondent filed petition under s.34 Arbitration Act on October 27, 1948 in Asansol Court for stay, rejected on August 20, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On October 27, 1948, respondent filed a petition under s. 34 of the Arbitration Act in the Asansol Court praying for the stay of the suit in view of the arbitration agreement in the original deed of partnership. This application was rejected on August 20, 1949.

facts.text: Respondent filed Civil Original Suit No. 71 of 1949 on January 3, 1949 in District Judge Court, Indore for Rs. 1,90,519 or accounts.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, on January 3, 1949, the respondent filed Civil Original Suit No. 71 of 1949 in the Court of the District Judge, Indore, against the appellant, and prayed for a decree for Rs. 1,90,519-0-6 against the appellant and further interest

facts.text: In Asansol written statement dated November 28, 1949, respondent denied jurisdiction referring to deed of dissolution.

anchor.surface_text: On November 28, 1949, the respondent filed his written statement in the Asansol Court. Paragraphs 19 and 21 of the written statement are With reference to paragraph 21 of the plaint, the defendant denies that the plaintiff has any cause of action against the defendant or that the alleged cause of action, the existence of which is denied, arose at Kajora Colliery. The defendant craves reference to the said deed of dissolution

facts.text: Issues struck on February 4, 1950 including jurisdiction and whether accounts rendered.

anchor.surface_text: Issues were struck on February 4, 1950. The first two issues are Has this Court jurisdiction to entertain and try this suit? Has the plaintiff rendered and satisfactorily explained the accounts of the partnership in terms of the deed of dissolution of partnership ?

facts.text: Respondent applied in December 1951 for stay under inherent powers in Asansol Court, rejected August 9, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: In December 1951, the respondent applied in the Court at Asansol for the stay of that suit in the exercise of its inherent powers. The application was rejected on August 9, 1952.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court confirmed rejection order on May 7, 1953 and directed expeditious hearing of jurisdiction issue.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Calcutta companyfirmed this order on May 7, 1953, and said We do number think that, in the circumstance of these cases and on the materials on record, those orders ought to be revised. ... As the preliminary issue No.1 in the two Asansol suits have been pending for over two years, it is only desirable that the said issues should be heard out at once.

facts.text: Appellant applied April 28, 1950 for stay of Indore suit under ss.10,151 CPC, rejected July 5, 1951, confirmed by Madhya Bharat HC August 20, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On April 28, 1950, the appellant applied to the Indore Court for staying that suit under ss. 10 and 151 Code of Civil Procedure. The application was opposed by the respondent ... The application for stay was rejected on July 5, 1951. The High Court of Madhya Bharat companyfirmed that order on August 20, 1953.

facts.text: Respondent applied September 14, 1953 under s.151 CPC in Indore Court to restrain appellant from continuing Asansol suit.

anchor.surface_text: It was in these circumstances that the respondent applied under s. 151, Code of Civil Procedure on September 14, 1953, to the Indore Court, for restraining the appellant from companytinuing the proceedings in the suit filed by him in the Court at Asansol.

facts.text: Additional District Judge Indore issued interim injunction restraining appellant from proceeding with Asansol suit.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional District Judge, Indore, issues interim injunction under O. XXXIX, Code of Civil Procedure, to the appellant restraining him from proceeding with his Asansol suit pending decision of the Indore suit

facts.text: Madhya Bharat High Court dismissed appellant's appeal against injunction on May 10, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the appeal by its order dated May 10, 1955.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal preferred by special leave against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order that the appellant has preferred this appeal, by special leave.

facts.text: Supreme Court held courts have inherent jurisdiction under s.151 CPC to issue temporary injunctions not covered by O.XXXIX.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the latter view is companyrect and that the Courts have inherent jurisdiction to issue temporary injunctions in circumstances which are number companyered by the provisions of O.XXXIX, Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside injunction order restraining appellant from proceeding in Asansol suit.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal with companyts, and set aside the order restraining the appellant from proceeding with the suit at Asansol.

facts.text: Shah J agreed appeal succeeds but disagreed on general inherent jurisdiction for injunctions outside O.39.

anchor.surface_text: SHAH, J.-I have perused the judgment delivered by Mr. Justice Dayal. I agree with the companyclusion that the appeal must succeed but I am unable to hold that civil companyrts generally have inherent jurisdiction

issues.text: Whether the Court could exercise its inherent powers when there were specific provisions in the Code of Civil Procedure for the issue of interim injunctions, they being s. 94 and XXXIX.

issues.text: What is the legal effect of the second proviso in the deed of dissolution on the maintainability of the suit in the Court at Asansol.

anchor.surface_text: The third point which came up for discussion at the hearing related to the legal effect of the second proviso in the deed of dissolution on the maintainability of the suit in the Court at Asansol. We do not propose to express any opinion on this question of jurisdiction

issues.text: Whether recourse to inherent powers under s.151 is justified when s.10 CPC provides specifically for stay of subsequent suits.

anchor.surface_text: When there is a special provision in the Code of Civil Procedure for dealing with the contingencies of two such suits being instituted, recourse to the inherent powers under s. 151 is not justified.

issues.text: Whether civil courts other than Chartered High Courts have inherent jurisdiction to issue temporary injunctions in cases not covered by O.XXXIX rr.1 and 2.

anchor.surface_text: I am unable to hold that civil courts generally have inherent jurisdiction in cases not covered by rr. 1 and 2 of O. 39, Civil Procedure Code to issue temporary injunctions restraining parties

arguments.claim: s.151 not controlled by Code provisions; inherent powers additional when no conflict.

anchor.surface_text: Further, the provisions of s. 151 of the Code make it clear that the inherent powers are not controlled by the provisions of the Code. Section 151 reads Nothing in this Code shall be deemed to limit or otherwise affect the inherent power of the Court to make such orders as may be necessary for the ends of the justice or to prevent abuse of the process of the Court.

arguments.claim: Padam Sen case supports inherent powers for commission outside s.75 O.XXVI; analogous for injunctions.

anchor.surface_text: A similar question about the powers of the Court to issue a commission in the exercise of its powers under s. 151 of the Code in circumstances not covered by s. 75 and Order XXVI, arose in Padam Sen v. The State of Uttar Pradesh and this Court held that the Court can issue a commission in such circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: On the second question, we are of opinion that in view of the facts of the case, the Courts below were in error in issuing a temporary injunction to the appellant restraining him from proceeding with the suit in the Asansol Court. The inherent powers are to be exercised by the Court in very exceptional circumstances, for which the Code lays down no procedure.

arguments.claim: Recourse to s.151 not justified when s.10 specifically deals with two suits; cannot bypass mandatory provision.

anchor.surface_text: The suit at Indore which had been instituted later, could be stayed in view of s. 10 of the Code. The provisions of that section are clear, definite and mandatory. A Court in which a subsequent suit has been filed is prohibited from proceeding with the trial of that suit in certain specified circumstances. When there is a special provision in the Code of Civil Procedure for dealing with the contingencies of two such suits being instituted, recourse to the inherent powers under s. 151 is not justified.

arguments.claim: Civil courts (non-Chartered HCs) have no inherent jurisdiction for injunctions outside O.39 rr.1,2; limited to s.94(c).

anchor.surface_text: SHAH, J.-I have perused the judgment delivered by Mr. Justice Dayal. I agree with the conclusion that the appeal must succeed but I am unable to hold that civil courts generally have inherent jurisdiction in cases not covered by rr. 1 and 2 of O. 39, Civil Procedure Code to issue temporary injunctions restraining parties

arguments.claim: Padam Sen precludes inherent powers expanding statutory limits like s.75 O.26 for commissions; analogous to injunctions.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of this Court in Padam Sen v. The State of Uttar Pradesh does not assist the case of the appellant. In Padam Sens case this Court was called upon in a original appeal to consider whether an order of a Munsiff appointing a commissioner for seizing certain account books of the plaintiff in a suit pending before the Munsiff was an order authorised by law.

holdings.text: the Courts have inherent jurisdiction to issue temporary injunctions in circumstances which are not covered by the provisions of O.XXXIX, Code of Civil Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the latter view is correct and that the Courts have inherent jurisdiction to issue temporary injunctions in circumstances which are not covered by the provisions of O.XXXIX, Code of Civil Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Code provisions not exhaustive; s.151 expressly saves inherent powers; no prohibition in s.94(c) or O.XXXIX; follows precedents like Dhaneshwar Nath, distinguishes contrary views; analogous to Padam Sen on commissions.

holdings.text: the Courts below were in error in issuing a temporary injunction to the appellant restraining him from proceeding with the suit in the Asansol Court.

anchor.surface_text: On the second question, we are of opinion that in view of the facts of the case, the Courts below were in error in issuing a temporary injunction to the appellant restraining him from proceeding with the suit in the Asansol Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inherent powers only for exceptional cases; Asansol suit prior, in competent court, not proven vexatious; no abuse despite contract clause; burden on applicant unmet; cites Cohen v Rothfield, Hyman v Helm.

holdings.text: When there is a special provision in the Code of Civil Procedure for dealing with the contingencies of two such suits being instituted, recourse to the inherent powers under s. 151 is not justified.

anchor.surface_text: When there is a special provision in the Code of Civil Procedure for dealing with the contingencies of two such suits being instituted, recourse to the inherent powers under s. 151 is not justified.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.10 provides mandatory procedure for subsequent suits; inherent powers cannot bypass specific provisions; s.35A, s.22 alternatives exist; Legislature contemplated multiplicity.

holdings.text: We therefore allow the appeal with costs, and set aside the order restraining the appellant from proceeding with the suit at Asansol.
